results.name: (1 + number of halving and tripling steps to reach 1 in the Collatz (3x+1) problem), or -1 if 1 is never reached.
comment: The number of steps (iterations of the map A006370) to reach 1 is given by A006577, this sequence counts 1 more. - _M. F. Hasler_, Nov 05 2017

When Collatz 3N+1 function is seen as an isometry over the dyadics, the halving step necessarily following each tripling is not counted, hence N -> N/2, if even, but N -> (3N+1)/2, if odd. Counting iterations of this map until reaching 1 leads to sequence A064433. [Michael Vielhaber (vielhaber(AT)gmail.com), Nov 18 2009]
reference: R. K. Guy, Unsolved Problems in Number Theory, E16.
link: Reinhard Zumkeller, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..10000
J. C. Lagarias, The 3x+1 problem and its generalizations, Amer. Math. Monthly, 92 (1985), 3-23.
Index entries for sequences related to 3x+1 (or Collatz) problem
formula: a(n) = f(n,1) with f(n,x) = if n=1 then x else f(A006370(n),x+1).
a(n) = length of n-th row in A070165. - _Reinhard Zumkeller_, May 11 2013
program: (PARI) a(n)=my(c=1); while(n>1, n=if(n%2, 3*n+1, n/2); c++); c \\ _Charles R Greathouse IV_, May 18 2015
print([a(n) for n in range(1, 101)]) # _Indranil Ghosh_, Apr 15 2017
